LEVIN APPOINTED
ADVISORY EDITOR
Langfeld And Perlmutter
Are Elected Managing Editors
Following the clearing up of a
difficulty which from the start
promised to culminate in undesirable complications, Norman S.
Heaney, at a meeting held Wednesday, was elected editor-in-chief of
THE NEWS-LETTER for the term
March, 1933, to March, 1934.
Two days prior to the election,
Hyman Levin, who retires from the
head of the paper today, definitely
stated his intention of not seeking
re-election and signified Heaney as
his choice for the editorship.
Others Elected

Price, 5 Cents

Fulfilling its final engagement of
the 1932-33 season, the Musical
Club journeys to Atlantic City on
Saturday, March 11, where it will
appear at the Hotel Chalfonte-Haddon Hall. This is the second time
that the club members have been
guests of the Hotel.
To date the club has presented
eight concerts, both in and out of
the State. Public appearances have
been made at five churches in the
city, and at Wilson College, Chambersburg, Pa., Maryland College for
Women, Lutherville, and at the
Maryland
Casualty Clubhouse,
where the annual home concert and
dance were held last Friday.

CLASS DUES NOW

Dr. Karl Herzfeld To Present Illustrated Lecture
At Assembly
Dr. Karl Herzfeld, professor of
physics, will present an illustrated
lecture on "Colleges and College
Life In Germany" at the assembly
next Thursday.
According to William H. Triplett, president of Student Council,
the assemblies for March 9 and
March 16 will feature Dr. Christie
and Dr. Broadus Mitchell, associate
professor of political economy. The
topics of their talks have as yet not
been announced.
Pi Delta Epsilon, national honorary journalistic fraternity, will
hold its annual public initiation,
April 6. A prominent journalist
will be secured as the principal
speaker. Tau Beta Pi and Omicron
Delta Kappa, engineering and active
honorary fraternities, respectively,
are to also publicly initiate at the
subsequent assemblies in April.

VETERANS WILL
REPORT TODAY
New Candidates To Meet
Next Monday At
4 P. M.
All members of last year's larrosse squad are urged by Coach
Ray Van Orman to appear at
Homewood field this afternoon at 4
p. m. New candidates should report at Homewood on Monday at
the same time.
The main purpose of this plan is
to permit the coach to learn what
old and new material is on hand,
and to dole out equipment more efficiently. By these arrangements
practice also will get under way
more quickly.

Hopkins Rally In Last Quarter Of Contest Falls
Short
Another defeat marked the closing of the basketball season, as far
as Hopkins is concerned, when a
Mt. St. Mary combine beat the Jays
last Tuesday night at Evergreen.
The final score was 32-29.
A Jay rally in the last quarter of
the contest fell short. From beginning to end the Mountaineers held
the upper hand both in attack and
defense.

An historical-critical edition of
Conrad Ferdinand Meyer's "Huttens Letzte Tage", which may be
considered as establishing the foundations for all future studies of that
work, has just been released by the
Johns Hopkins Press. The author
of the volume is Dr. R. B. Roulston,
professor of German here.
The project has been undertaken,
it was stated, with the aim first, of
"establishing the true history of the
text of the work of the Swiss poet,
and second, of rendering accessible
to students of Meyer all of the material necessary for the study of his
poem, within the compass of one
volume."

Brooklyn Wrestlers Beat
Hopkins Matmen By
23-5 Score
Brooklyn Polytechnic proved sufficiently strong to conquer the Johns
Hopkins grapplers last Saturday
night, 23-5. Only Captain Hamilton Sears, wrestling in the 165-1b.
class, was able to chalk up a victory.
Next to Captain Sears, Bachman,
who grapples in the 115-1b. class,
gave the best exhibition.
The curtain will be brought down
on the season this week end. Tonight Gallaudet will be encountered
at Washington, and tomorrow
night Western Maryland will be engaged at Westminster.

Dr.Seymour To Deliver
Eight Shaw Lectures
Beginning March 6
"American Diplomacy During the
Word War" will be the general topic
of a series of eight lectures, to be
given at the Hopkins, beginning
March 6 by Dr. Charles Seymour,
Sterling professor of history and
provost of Yale University.
The lectures are being delivered
under the auspices of the Albert
Shaw lectureship and of the Page
School of International Relations.
"The German Appeal to Wilson"
and "The Negotiation of the Armistice", to be given March 6 and 8,
respectively, will be open to the
public.

Mounts Always Lead

With the exception of parts of the
last period, the Mounts retained at
least a seven-point lead. The visiting team showed keen ability at retrieving rebounds under its own and
under Hopkins's basket. Likewise,
the Mounts' center man, Hopkins,
constantly obtained the tap-off.
Thus his team had possession of the
ball most of the time.
The second cause of the Jay defeat was the performance of the
Lynch brothers. Tom thrilled the
audience with his sharp cutting for
the basket, while Joe fed passes to
his teammates and guarded Caleb
Kelly without any difficulty.
The Black and Blue team's loss
resulted from faults that have been
the cause of almost all its defeats.
In the first place, the team tried to
play in a manner suitable against a
zone defense, while the Mounts
started with a zone defense and immediately switched to man-for-man
style.

At a recent meeting of the track
team, Coach Waldo Hambleton emphasized the need for more candidates in the middle distances and

According to Manager Bruce
Herman, there will be only two
home meets this year. Delaware
University will provide the opposition for the Jay trackmen on

Blue field on May 20. This marks
the first time in four years that the
Terp-Jay meet will take place at
Homewood.
Present indications point to a
successful campaign. Most of the
members of last year's squad are
again available for service, and will
be supplemented by a group of
promising freshmen.
Equipment has been given out to
members of last year's varsity. Candidates are urged to come out. Praefizz is held daily at 4 P. M. at

set a slow, methodical pace instead

HYMAN LEVIN
Hyman Levin, who is a junior in the
College of Arts and Sciences at the Hopkins, today is succeeded to the position
of editor-in-chief of THE NEWS-LETTER.
In retiring from the head of the paper,
Levin becomes, by special appointment,
advisory editor-in-chief until March, 1934.
Named to the honorary post in recognition of his work in the improvement of the
newspaper, he will serve as a non-voting
member of the board of control and as
adviser to the staff.

Maurice R. Chassin, who is taking special courses at the School of Hygiene
and Public Health, retires from his position of business manager. He will be
graduated from the A.B. school in June.
He is a member of 0. D. K., captain of
track team, treasurer of Pi Delta Epsilon,
and advertising manager of The Hullabaloo staff.
Both retiring NEWS-LETTER heads were
elected on March 24, 1932.

With several other publications
forthcoming the Johns Hopkins
Press recently published "The Protection of Nationals", by Frederick
Sherwood Dunn, associate member
of the Page School and Creswell
Lecturer on international law in The
Johns Hopkins University.
As a study in international law the
author re-examines the whole subject of the application of law to international questions. He seeks to
develop a conception of the subject
that is more in line with modern theories of jurisprudence, rejecting the
usual conceived difficulties in the international field.

Hopkins Varsity Club
Makes Changes In
Its Constitution
Eligibility For Entrance Into Group
Extended To Athlete Who
Wins Major Letter
A complete reorganization was
made and a new constitution composed at a meeting of the Varsity
Club held Monday.
The eligibility for entrance into
the group was extended by the new
constitution to any Hopkins athlete
who wins his major letter. It also
states that the president of the group
must call a meeting at least once a
month and that any member absenting himself from three consecutive
meetings will lose his status in the
club.
The formation of an athletic
honor society, with membership
limited to those who are outstanding in athletic ability, was proposed
at the meeting.

Look at this remarkable lady.
perfect heads... all attached to a normal body. She
appears to sit on the stage, with the lower part of her

nod. She can talk, laugh, and sing—all at the same

EXPLANATION:

Audiences used to pay an extra fee to go behind the
scenes to see how this trick was worked. They discovered that the three-headed woman was merely a
reflection in a mirror. The glass showed the heads of
three girls but the body of only one. The other two
were cleverly hidden so that only their heads showed
in the mirror.

Hopkins Rally In Last Quarter Of Contest Falls
Short
Another defeat marked the closing of the basketball season, as far
as Hopkins is concerned, when a
Mt. St. Mary combine beat the Jays
last Tuesday night at Evergreen.
The final score was 32-29.
A Jay rally in the last quarter of
the contest fell short. From beginning to end the Mountaineers held
the upper hand both in attack and
defense.

An historical-critical edition of
Conrad Ferdinand Meyer's "Huttens Letzte Tage", which may be
considered as establishing the foundations for all future studies of that
work, has just been released by the
Johns Hopkins Press. The author
of the volume is Dr. R. B. Roulston,
professor of German here.
The project has been undertaken,
it was stated, with the aim first, of
"establishing the true history of the
text of the work of the Swiss poet,
and second, of rendering accessible
to students of Meyer all of the material necessary for the study of his
poem, within the compass of one
volume."

Brooklyn Wrestlers Beat
Hopkins Matmen By
23-5 Score
Brooklyn Polytechnic proved sufficiently strong to conquer the Johns
Hopkins grapplers last Saturday
night, 23-5. Only Captain Hamilton Sears, wrestling in the 165-1b.
class, was able to chalk up a victory.
Next to Captain Sears, Bachman,
who grapples in the 115-1b. class,
gave the best exhibition.
The curtain will be brought down
on the season this week end. Tonight Gallaudet will be encountered
at Washington, and tomorrow
night Western Maryland will be engaged at Westminster.

Dr.Seymour To Deliver
Eight Shaw Lectures
Beginning March 6
"American Diplomacy During the
Word War" will be the general topic
of a series of eight lectures, to be
given at the Hopkins, beginning
March 6 by Dr. Charles Seymour,
Sterling professor of history and
provost of Yale University.
The lectures are being delivered
under the auspices of the Albert
Shaw lectureship and of the Page
School of International Relations.
"The German Appeal to Wilson"
and "The Negotiation of the Armistice", to be given March 6 and 8,
respectively, will be open to the
public.

Mounts Always Lead

With the exception of parts of the
last period, the Mounts retained at
least a seven-point lead. The visiting team showed keen ability at retrieving rebounds under its own and
under Hopkins's basket. Likewise,
the Mounts' center man, Hopkins,
constantly obtained the tap-off.
Thus his team had possession of the
ball most of the time.
The second cause of the Jay defeat was the performance of the
Lynch brothers. Tom thrilled the
audience with his sharp cutting for
the basket, while Joe fed passes to
his teammates and guarded Caleb
Kelly without any difficulty.
The Black and Blue team's loss
resulted from faults that have been
the cause of almost all its defeats.
In the first place, the team tried to
play in a manner suitable against a
zone defense, while the Mounts
started with a zone defense and immediately switched to man-for-man
style.

Track Coach Asks For
More Candidates At
Track Practice
At a recent meeting of the track
team, Coach Waldo Hambleton emphasized the need for more candidates in the middle distances and
the field events.
According to Manager Bruce
Herman, there will be only two
home meets this year. Delaware
University will provide the opposition for the Jay trackmen on
April 15 at Homewood, while
Maryland will invade the Black and
Blue field on May 20. This marks
the first time in four years that the
Terp-Jay meet will take place at
Homewood.
Present indications point to a
successful campaign. Most of the
members of last year's squad are
again available for service, and will
be supplemented by a group of
promising freshmen.
Equipment has been given out to
members of last year's varsity. Candidates are urged to come out. Praefizz is held daily at 4 P. M. at

HYMAN LEVIN
Hyman Levin, who is a junior in the
College of Arts and Sciences at the Hopkins, today is succeeded to the position
of editor-in-chief of THE NEWS-LETTER.
In retiring from the head of the paper,
Levin becomes, by special appointment,
advisory editor-in-chief until March, 1934.
Named to the honorary post in recognition of his work in the improvement of the
newspaper, he will serve as a non-voting
member of the board of control and as
adviser to the staff.

Maurice R. Chassin, who is taking special courses at the School of Hygiene
and Public Health, retires from his position of business manager. He will be
graduated from the A.B. school in June.
He is a member of 0. D. K., captain of
track team, treasurer of Pi Delta Epsilon,
and advertising manager of The Hullabaloo staff.
Both retiring NEWS-LETTER heads were
elected on March 24, 1932.

With several other publications
forthcoming the Johns Hopkins
Press recently published "The Protection of Nationals", by Frederick
Sherwood Dunn, associate member
of the Page School and Creswell
Lecturer on international law in The
Johns Hopkins University.
As a study in international law the
author re-examines the whole subject of the application of law to international questions. He seeks to
develop a conception of the subject
that is more in line with modern theories of jurisprudence, rejecting the
usual conceived difficulties in the international field.

from the Carnegie Endowment
every year. The Fortnightly Summary, a periodic reading on international events, also sent by the
Carnegie Endowment, is distributed
among the members.
A speaker addresses the club at a
monthly luncheon meeting. After
the luncheon there is a group meeting with a general discussion on international events, one of the members delivering a paper. No new
advisor has been chosen since Dr.
Willoughby, former advisor, announced his intention of resigning.

Hopkins Varsity Club
Makes Changes In
Its Constitution
Eligibility For Entrance Into Group
Extended To Athlete Who
Wins Major Letter
A complete reorganization was
made and a new constitution composed at a meeting of the Varsity
Club held Monday.
The eligibility for entrance into
the group was extended by the new
constitution to any Hopkins athlete
who wins his major letter. It also
states that the president of the group
must call a meeting at least once a
month and that any member absenting himself from three consecutive
meetings will lose his status in the
club.
The formation of an athletic
honor society, with membership
limited to those who are outstanding in athletic ability, was proposed
at the meeting.

Look at this remarkable lady.
perfect heads... all attached to a normal body. She

EXPLANATION:

Audiences used to pay an extra fee to go behind the
scenes to see how this trick was worked. They discovered that the three-headed woman was merely a
reflection in a mirror. The glass showed the heads of
three girls but the body of only one. The other two
were cleverly hidden so that only their heads showed
in the mirror.
